name: Buenos Aires
fun_fact: Fun fact: Buenos Aires is the birthplace of tango, a dance born in the working-class districts in the late 1800s from a fusion of Candomb칠 (African slaves), Habanera (Cuban), Mazurka (Polish), and Polka (Czech) dances. The Argentine upper classes shunned it until it became wildly popular in Paris after WWI - then suddenly Buenos Aires elite embraced it because it was 'fashionable in Paris.' UNESCO declared tango Intangible Cultural Heritage in 2009.

hero_dishes.name: Asado (Argentine Barbecue)
hero_dishes.description: Argentina's national dish - beef charcoal or wood-grilled on a large parrilla grill, including chorizo, morcilla, mollejas (sweetbreads), ri침칩n (kidney), chinchul칤n (chitterlings)
hero_dishes.origin_story: Until the mid-1800s, huge herds of wild cattle roamed the pampas (fertile grasslands around Buenos Aires). Gauchos - colorful horsemen folk heroes similar to North American cowboys - developed a passion for asado. They roasted beef close to slow-burning quebracho tree wood on skewered metal 'asador' structures. The wood produced little smoke and gave rich flavor. In the 19th-20th centuries, as Argentina urbanized and the cattle industry flourished, asado became a festive tradition for Independence Day, May Revolution Day, weekends, birthdays, and weddings. It's not just about meat - it's a social gathering where people talk over Malbec wine from the moment the fire is made.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Aires Criollos - beloved by locals for no-frills atmosphere and perfectly grilled meat (bife de chorizo, entra침a) over wood fire. Parrilla Pe침a near Avenida C칩rdoba has 'none of the tourist polish but all the authentic flavors' with generous, juicy portions.

hero_dishes.name: Empanadas
hero_dishes.description: Small pastries filled with meat, cheese, sweet corn, and many other fillings, common at parties, picnics, and as meal starters
hero_dishes.origin_story: From the Spanish verb 'empanar' (to wrap in bread), empanadas trace back to Galicia and Northern Portugal during Moorish invasions. Spanish immigrants brought the recipe to Argentina in the 16th century. The decorative folded edge (repulgue) isn't just aesthetic - it identifies the flavor, since they're traditionally ordered by the dozen with mixed flavors.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional bodegones (dinner-style restaurants) throughout the city, especially 'Bares Notables' - establishments protected by law to maintain original facades and interiors

hero_dishes.name: Milanesa (especially Milanesa Napolitana)
hero_dishes.description: Thin slice of beef or chicken hammered thin, coated in breadcrumbs, then baked or fried. Napolitana version adds tomatoes, cheese, and ham
hero_dishes.origin_story: Introduced by Italian immigrants, it's a variation of Milan's 'Cotoletta alla milanese' (similar to Wiener Schnitzel). The Milanesa Napolitana version is very Argentinian - invented in Buenos Aires in the 1940s at a restaurant called Napoli on Avenida Corrientes. Legend says the chef accidentally created it while trying to save a burnt milanesa by adding cheese, ham, and tomatoes.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: El Preferido de Palermo in the heart of Palermo - a favorite among locals for traditional Argentine comfort food. 'The star of the menu is their milanesa, a perfectly breaded and fried cutlet that comes in portions so large it practically covers the entire plate.'

hero_dishes.name: Bodeg칩n Classics
hero_dishes.description: Hearty dishes in generous portions from vintage bodegones with wooden decor, football memorabilia, and family photos
hero_dishes.origin_story: Bodegones are the quintessential Porte침o dining experience - dinner-style restaurants offering diverse menus from pasta to seafood, beef, pork, chicken. A select few hold 'Bares Notables' distinction, protected by law and required to maintain original facades and interiors with government approval for any changes.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: El Viejo Vulcano in San Telmo offers traditional Argentine dining a little off the beaten path, popular with locals for affordability. La Sarita is inspired by classic bodegones, recalling a golden era with long tables and professional waiters.

hero_dishes.name: Pizza Porte침a
hero_dishes.description: Thick 'al molde' style pizza with thick crust, barely any sauce, and abundant cheese. Fugazzeta (stuffed with mozzarella, topped with onions)
hero_dishes.origin_story: With 6 million people of Italian descent in S칚o Paulo and massive Italian immigration to Buenos Aires, pizza culture is huge. Proper Porte침o pizza is found on Avenida Corrientes. Fugazzeta was invented at Banchero in La Boca in 1932 - a thick doughy base stuffed with mozzarella and topped with onions.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Guerrin on Avenida Corrientes is an institution. If you only eat pizza once in Buenos Aires, go here. El Cuartito 'remains as traditional as ever.' Banchero in La Boca (founded 1932) is credited with inventing fugazzeta.

signature_drinks.name: Mate
signature_drinks.description: Traditional South American 'tea' made from dried, chopped yerba leaves drunk from a gourd, with natural stimulant mate칤na (similar to caffeine)
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: In a city that never sleeps, mate keeps the porte침o motor running. Generally drunk in groups among family and friends in social settings. The mate is passed around, each person drinking the water out and passing back to the server to refill. The epitome of local culture - no Argentine barbecue is complete without mate (and a bottle of Malbec).

signature_drinks.name: Fernet and Coke (Fernet con Coca)
signature_drinks.description: Italian liqueur Fernet-Branca mixed with Coca-Cola - Argentina's 'unofficial national drink' called Fernandito or Porte침ito
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Argentina consumes more than 75% of all fernet produced globally! The cocktail became popular among youth in C칩rdoba in the 1980s and spread nationwide through advertising. Fernet and vermouth are tabletop staples in Buenos Aires, as common as salt and pepper. Argentines drink an estimated 19 million liters of fernet annually (80% of world consumption). More than just a drink - it's a cultural icon at social gatherings, bars, and celebrations, symbolizing unity and tradition.

signature_drinks.name: Malbec Wine
signature_drinks.description: Argentina's signature red wine, especially from Mendoza region
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with asado from the moment the fire is being made. The Argentine strain of Malbec has become internationally renowned. Essential at family gatherings and weekend barbecues.

food_culture_notes: Porte침os are late eaters: lunch 12:30-1:30 PM (locals eat closer to 1:30), dinner starts 8:30 PM but locals eat at 9 PM weekdays, 10-11 PM weekends
Traditional porte침o cuisine blends Mediterranean cooking (heavy Italian and Spanish immigrant influence) with creole, native Andean, and neighboring Latin American ideas
Buenos Aires population exploded from 180,000 (1869) to 1.5 million (1914) due to immigration - 2 million arrived from Europe in early 1900s (half Italian, third Spanish)
Lunfardo argot (slang) originated in prisons and spread to all porte침os - uses Italian dialects, Portuguese, African, Caribbean, English words - mostly heard in tango lyrics now
Many Spanish immigrants from Galicia - Spaniards still generically called 'gallegos' (Galicians)
'Cien barrios porte침os' (one hundred porte침o neighborhoods) is a common expression from a 1940s tango, though Buenos Aires only has 48 official barrios
Buenos Aires International Book Fair described as 'perhaps the most important and largest annual literary event in the Spanish-speaking world'
